perturbation.original_text: Supplier will not sell, ship or otherwise  dispose of any such merchandise except upon the order of Purchaser or Playboy; (iii) Supplier will never make, cause others to make or assist others in making, any claim whatsoever to any or all of the Playboy Properties or any trademark,  copyright, designation, name, phrase, design or symbol similar thereto in connection with the manufacture, advertising,  promotion, sale or distribution of merchandise; and (iv) Supplier will defend, indemnify and hold harmless Purchaser and Playboy and the distributors and dealers and the officers and employees of each of the foregoing against all liability  whatsoever which may be incurred by them or any of them as a result of any alleged defects in material or workmanship  in the merchandise covered by this Contract.
perturbation.changed_text: Supplier may sell, ship or otherwise dispose of any such merchandise at their own discretion; (iii) Supplier may make claims to the Playboy Properties with written consent from the Purchaser; and (iv) Supplier will defend, indemnify and hold harmless Purchaser excluding Playboy, and the distributors and dealers and the officers and employees of each of the foregoing against liability that is solely based on gross negligence of Supplier.
perturbation.explanation: The original text strictly prohibits the supplier from disposing of merchandise without approval, making claims to Playboy Properties, and requires broad indemnification. The modified text contradicts this by allowing disposal at the supplier's discretion, permitting claims with consent (potentially infringing on Playboy's rights), and limiting indemnification to gross negligence and excluding Playboy from the indemnification agreement entirely. This is misaligned with standard IP protection and indemnification expectations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trademark Law, Copyright Law, Contract Law (Indemnification)

perturbation.original_text: Supplier will, upon request from Purchaser or Playboy, deliver to Purchaser or will destroy in the presence of Purchaser  or its representative(s), all molds, designs or any other elements used in reproducing any or all of the Playboy Properties.
perturbation.changed_text: Supplier will, upon request from Purchaser, but not Playboy, either deliver to Purchaser or retain all molds, designs or any other elements used in reproducing any or all of the Playboy Properties.
perturbation.explanation: By removing Playboy's right to request delivery or destruction and allowing the supplier to retain molds and designs, the modified text conflicts with typical intellectual property protection measures. This creates a contradiction, as the original agreement suggests strict control over Playboy Properties, whereas the modified text allows the supplier to maintain possession of elements used in reproducing those properties, potentially leading to unauthorized use. Under United States Copyright law, Playboy as the copyright holder has the right to say when their property must be destroyed if no longer authorized to be used, and not giving Playboy the right to destroy would be an issue.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Copyright Law, Trademark Law, Contract Law

perturbation.original_text: This Contract may not be modified or terminated except in writing, and no claimed modification, termination or waiver  shall be binding unless also signed by an authorized representative of Playboy.
perturbation.changed_text: This Contract may be modified or terminated through verbal agreement; a written record is encouraged but not required. A modification, termination, or waiver is binding only if acknowledged by the Purchaser.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause stipulates that all modifications, terminations, or waivers must be in writing and signed by Playboy. The modified text directly contradicts this by allowing verbal agreements and removing Playboy's required signature, thereby undermining the enforceability of the agreement and creating significant legal uncertainty. This contradicts basic contract law principles requiring written modification for specific contract types, particularly those involving intellectual property licenses.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law (Statute of Frauds, Modification Clauses)
